title: Before 1 September 2021, who will be the first to fly successfully to space, Jeff Bezos or Richard Branson?
possible_answers: Neither will fly successfully to space before 1 September 2021
preds: So long as he lands safely
Mothership is already at 40,000 feet (launch expected at 45,000): http://www.virgingalactic.com/
Branson has taken off. I'm optimistic about safety.
As Branson is set to fly very soon and assuming that counts as space then he will almost certainly be first barring an accident
Trimming the numbers a tad can always give Jeff a boost later if need be, such is the fickle nature of algorithms Standby for Action (Cue Bongos)  Anything could happen in the next half hour

A 1.5 hour delay was just announced, "but we are on track to fly today with a newly scheduled time." https://twitter.com/virgingalactic/status/1414179512749752323
http://www.virgingalactic.com/
Launch window opens in T - 2 :) Good luck  to #Unity22  :)

It looks on for today - "UK businessman Sir Richard Branson is about to realise a lifetime's ambition by flying to the edge of space.    He'll ride his Virgin Galactic rocket plane on Sunday to an altitude where the sky turns black and the Earth's horizon curves away into the distance.     The entrepreneur says he wants to evaluate the experience before allowing paying customers aboard next year.   The vehicle will set off for the 1.5-hour mission above New Mexico at about 08:30 local US time (15:30 BST)." https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-57790040

Keeping the door open a bit here, there is room enough for Sir Richard to have another go on his birthday next Sunday, the flight has to be successful for it to count in terms of the question Jeff Bezos is set to go on July 20th weather and everything else permitting,  although there might be enough time to get in a second launch before month end

Tomorrow is the D day for Branson if he’s gonna do it good luck
https://www.virgingalactic.com/
One hundred % right! 
Great flight!

Virgin's attempt; weather could be a factor:
- Rain and scattered afternoon thunderstorms in the forecast for Sunday 7/11 in Truth or Consequences, NM. Wind speed ~20 MPH.
- Virgin did fly in sunny conditions on a hot day with wind that strength 5/22: https://www.wunderground.com/history/daily/us/nm/truth-or-consequences/KLRU/date/2021-5-22 however they flew in the morning.

If either is successful over the next few weeks, will it spur Space tourism in the short term I wonder?  Branson seems more of a dare-devil and willing to take risks, and would surely love to stick one in Jeff's eye.    Increasing % for both him ahead of weekend, but also for Neither https://www.space.com/virgin-galactic-richard-branson-spaceflight-webcast

With Branson scheduled for this Sunday, I am trying to think about what factors could lead Bezos to jump him. I certainly don't think Bezos could schedule a flight so quickly, so I think it would have to be a series of events delaying Branson (as opposed to moving Bezos forward). This could be COVID-19 uncertainties; fortunately, however, vaccinations have mostly put COVID behind us -- so I don't think that really lowers Branson's probability much. Moreover, if there are factors which may move Branson back, it is entirely possible that they could also move Bezos back.

Richard Branson has the most to gain by being the first and will take fewer precautions than Bezos to be the first to launch.  COVID-19 uncertainties are increasing, which lower the probability that either will launch before 9/1/21.
Countdown is still on. Weather looks a little hot Saturday but no precipitation.

Although both are highly competitive (to understate it), Branson seems to me to consistently been more brash, aggressive, dogged in his pursuits for a longer period of time and probably does not want to hand over any imagined crown just yet. It may be possible that those exact same reasons will propel Bezos to win this race of technology, science and egos.
I upgraded downward due do the comment from @Dominic-Cooney that suggests that Virgin's recent track record it about 50%.
Bezos is scheduled a few days after Branson so if Branson stumbles Bezos might get in
Imo, all that money would be better spent mitigating climate change, planting trees, ending polio, or feeding kids who don't have enough to eat.

Branson has a 3 times proven path to 55 miles and has a schedule that puts him in space in 4 days. There are still variables such as weather or unforeseen events that can derail this plan. Given Bezos has plans for July 20, there will be the potential for bravado involved in rushing this up. One of these two men will have been in space prior to Sept 1, 2021.
Space is much more dangerous than you think. Better questions need to be asked in relation to human space flight.
Weather in "Truth or Consequences" New Mexico looks fine (high of 92, partly cloudy) for Saturday. So Branson not meeting the deadline will mostly come down to technical details rather than weather.
There are 5 days left before Virgin Galactic makes the flight ; it's unlikely that there be a new reversal from Bezos. Moreover, the intersection of Branson & Bezos don't fly is rather unlikely.
Blue Origin has always valued being slow and steady, and I think the crowd's 79% is a bit low

3 days after the announcement and 1 week before the scheduled event, VG tweets an invitation for watching the event live, while Branson himself tweets a daily countdown:
https://twitter.com/virgingalactic/status/1411774773265256449
https://twitter.com/richardbranson/status/1411656135384440834

Bezos' flight is unlikely to be moved up because the date is chosen to coincide with an Apollo anniversary, so assume Branson flies first. There's no indication Virgin can turn around quickly so they have one shot. Virgin's recent track record seems to be about 50% success rate. Blue Origin has made 14 successful spaceflights; let's say it is 95% reliable. Round neither is successful up because, god forbid something happens to Branson, one in one hundred that Bezos might reconsider.
Branson had announced an earlier attempt

"  Sir Richard Branson has named the date he'll fly to the edge of space. It will be 11 July, or very soon after.  He'll be a passenger in the back of the Unity rocket plane his Virgin Galactic company has been developing in the US for the better part of two decades.   The vehicle can climb to an altitude of 90km (295,000ft), giving those onboard a few minutes of weightlessness and a view of the curvature of the Earth.      If the mission does indeed go ahead on that Sunday, it would mean Sir Richard stealing a march on his rival in sub-orbital space tourism, fellow billionaire Jeff Bezos.      The founder of the online retail empire Amazon.com has sunk a fortune into his hobby of building rockets and has announced his own trip to the edge of space on 20 July.  " https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-57689855
https://www.cbsnews.com/news/richard-branson-joins-company-crew-for-july-11-spaceflight/

Branson is scheduled first, but I wouldn't be surprised that his 'race' to be first back-fires and the flight has to be cancelled. Bezos has been planning this trip for months with his step-down from Amazon. Blue Origin just gives me slightly more confidence in their abilities. Overall, tilting towards Brandon due to the schedule but not confident.
Two self made men risking it all and the world gets to watch the show for free. Weather, equipment, fitness, many things could get the way of success.

While Bezos’ space flight will mark the first time Blue Origin has sent human passengers to space, Virgin Galactic has run three successful space flight tests, so far, including one in May that included two pilots. Virgin’s July 11 launch will include four passengers, including Branson.
https://www.cnbc.com/2021/07/02/branson-vs-bezos-how-the-two-space-bound-billionaires-stack-up.html Plus, my guess is if RB's flight is not successful, then there'll be a delay in JB's flight. That's why I'm assigning higher probability to neither will ... than that of JB.

The announced dates differ by only 9 days (July 11 vs July 20). Virgin has already set up a countdown on their homepage targeted at July 11 [1], but in fact the announcement reads as "the flight window for the next rocket-powered test flight of its SpaceShipTwo Unity opens July 11, pending weather and technical checks" [2]. Still, there seems to be enough time for Branson to beat Bezos, as the scenario of the Blue Origin launch moving earlier is highly unlikely. ----------------------
[1] http://www.virgingalactic.com/
[2] https://www.virgingalactic.com/articles/virgin-galactic-announces-first-fully-crewed-spaceflight/

Branson is due to start from the 11th of July, I am open to correction but Weather conditions are slightly less of a problem for Virgin  Would think he makes it a week later on July 18th  The return safely caveat is noted

Branson is on an earlier scheduled flight, so has a better chance on that basis alone. Both would not be going if they were not confident in the process.  And are both already scheduled in for July.   So there is a good chance of failure in anything like this, but it’s not that extreme.

Branson is scheduled for July 11 for an "up-and-down test flight. Bezos for 9 days later on July 20.  Both are short rides expected to pass the above 50 miles boundary of space "just above the discernible atmosphere for a few minutes of weightlessness and spectacular views before returning to Earth" Both seem on target for the announced dates but weather could interfere.  https://www.cbsnews.com/news/richard-branson-joins-company-crew-for-july-11-spaceflight/
Branson's scheduled first, but both Virgin Galactic and Blue Origin are in early non-routine parts of their program.
Branson has announced plans to launch on 7/11, so while I won't give him a 100% chance I'll give him the big edge as of now.
Jeff has had more success than Richard on setting up space flight. But space flight is really hard and weather and other factors play are role so 10% chance they both fail.
Branson is scheduled now for July 11!  He may not make it out but he will make it out first.
